{"step_by_step_thinking": "The infant's symptoms of respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypoplasia, low-set ears, retrognathia, and abnormal extremity development suggest a congenital disorder. Hepatosplenomegaly is often associated with metabolic or hematologic disorders, which doesn't fit the clinical picture. Posterior urethral valves are a cause of urinary tract obstruction in male infants, but they don't typically cause the other symptoms mentioned. Duodenal atresia is associated with Down syndrome, but the other symptoms don't fit this diagnosis. Rocker bottom feet, however, are a characteristic feature of Edward's syndrome (Trisomy 18), which also includes the other symptoms mentioned: pulmonary hypoplasia, low-set ears, retrognathia, and abnormal extremity development.", "answer_choice": "C. Rocker bottom feet"}
